comments.commentBody: I love M_C for a vowel run / wink

Recco for "KOKOmo" Lasz.

BTW, how do we know that the lizard doesn't know? Has anyone tried to teach sign lanuage to a lizard, and ask it directly?

When I saw the Patrick Blindauer/ACMe byline, I thought this was going to be one fancy puzzle. Honestly, I was a little disappointed. Obviously they are not on this earth to please me. A vowel run? And why M_C exactly? I see no particular importance to these over any other two consonants, unless it's a reference to something I'm not getting. I tend to agree with Deb on vowel runs.

Favorite entry: BASILISK from the Greek βασιλίσκος (basilískos) or "little king," a legendary reptile reputed to be king of serpents with the power to cause death with a single glance.

The common BASILISK (Basiliscus basiliscus) is a lizard found in Central and South American rainforests near rivers and streams. It is also known as the Jesus lizard for its ability to run on the surface of water using the water's surface tension, and the flaps between its toes to create a larger surface and a pocket of air. Of course, the lizard doesn't know this.

I also liked ODIUM, CURTSY, TROPE, ENOKI (a little above the average Tuesday fill) and the double Beatles reference.

Here are The Beach Boys in KOKOmo:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9_5_AD9wXuY

Good night.

Boehner should allow a vote on the clean CR that has been sitting on his desk dating back to the time the GOP remembered why they wanted to shut down the government.

As another commenter posted, why exactly is there this perception that the GOP is doing the Democrats a favor by re-opening the government?
As part time legislators, the House Republicans actually can introduce legislation to do exactly what you said. Why do they need to resort to extortion if their ideas are so popular?

Another way of understanding these people; their brains tells them it can kill them and yet go on living.
And it is one the reasons I believe they are vanguard of the second rebellion; I am sure people will say I am shrill, but I just don't see a way around them. They are almost similar to Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, when they finally got the legal power to effect (absolute) change, and the only way around them was an illegal and unconstitutional action by military. Fanaticism, as practiced, is the same anywhere whether with a gun, or a gerrymandered ballot. And their unspoken rallying cry; "its going to be done (my) way, or I am going to burn the nation down, of course in order to save it."

Prof. Stiglitz --
Don't the national governments of those countries that do nothing about inequality consequently find their legitimacy crumbling? Isn't that what we're already seeing in many places (perhaps now here when distrust and disaffection with the federal government is at an all time high)? And isn't this largely because of the mobile capital problem you cite? Seems to me that national governments have less and less capacity -- as do their officials, increasingly succumbing to rising financial temptation and dependency -- to restrain the socially debilitating effects of global corporations. If so, then this is one key way that inequality leads to political instability.

A certain amount of inequality in wealth is natural and even desirable. But extreme inequality, especially when its clearly the product of "excessive financialization", as you say, which has bled the real economy dry, reflects gross injustice. Real wealth production has always been a broadly social affair, the whole society--or overwhelming majority-- contributing. When wealth distribution doesn't reflect real contribution of labor, that's an unjust system, and its political leadership will likely suffer, at the hands of an aggrieved citizenry, a crisis of legitimacy.

In the great national conversation about inequality, it's time we began talking about injustice and the need and basis for just governance-- the foundation of the legitimacy of governments.

She said she's scheduled to fly Tuesday (tomorrow, well later today) so there's an outside chance she'll have a moment to let us know.  She seemed pretty determined to go no matter what, and there's always plenty to do before a trip...
Leapy, it's tomorrow already here, also in the UK, that' why I wondered.....
Right. For some reason, I had the idea she was taking a night flight. At this point, we just have to wait for word, hope she does all right.
No avatars here today.  Anybody else?

The defecit is largely American wealth. The government borrows money from me (a am a bank). This looks like a bond, which is now in my possession. I then sell this bond for money, or I hold it in reserve so that I can lend my other money out. Because the bond is valuable, I can lend against its resale value. If the government defaults, say goodbye to your bank accounts, as all those bonds just became worthless.

I don't support defaulting, but I do support balancing the budget. My taxes went up a lot in January, so I don't want more tax hikes.

Spending cuts sound better, like increasing the Medicare age, cutting the military, and intensely limiting SS disability. I know a guy who has zero use of his legs and limited use of his arms and works 50 hours per week, and I get tired of people trying to weasel onto disability. Limiting medical spending on those who can't pay to services with a high cost/benefit ratio would help, and I don't care of Sarah Palin calls it a "death panel." There are a lot of special interest subsidies that can go away, from farm price supports to renewable energy to overpaying government unions.

I'm aware of the size of the deficit. These cuts will be real and deep, but we'll be better off for having done it. Most state and local governments already require balanced budgets.
You would be far better off if Senator Reid stepped aside, fortunately that won't happen! With a "friend" like Harry the president doesn't need any enemies.

Ms. Regas is absolutely right. Save face for Republican extremists? Why? Should people have an impulse to save face for the mob when they blackmail innocent victims?

Our entire nation, in addition to the Democrats in Congress, is being blackmailed over the government shutdown and whether to raise the debt ceiling. The guiding principle for Democrats (and Independents like Bernie Sanders) should be to "win," which is to say they need to do what is right, responsible, and has integrity: They need to not give ANYTHING away and should agree to talk only after the government is reopened and the debt ceiling is raised for one year.

Only then should they pursue speaking with the Republicans, out of a spirit of responsible collaboration and a desire to better our nation.

But give in so blackmailers can save face? So they can return another time to torture more concessions out of the responsible majority?

You have raised a good point regarding verification of income.  This is a needless demand from the Republicans, and will slow down almost to a standstill the implementation of the law.  Verification is accomplished when the insured files an income tax return.  The opposition to the ACA seems hellbent on trying anything to impede the smooth running of the plan.  I hope the Democrats don't agree to this, and I will be contacting my representatives in Congress expressing my displeasure with the idea.

As others will comment, there are many reasons why this deal is unacceptable. First and foremost, it will set a precedent of requiring verification above and beyond what is already provided for in the law. If that isn't bad enough, allowing such extra verification to be required will impose additional burdens on the healthcare delivery system. This provides yet another way for Republicans to undermine the very function of the ACA.

Then, after what we're going through, to willingly go through it again? At this point, with public sentiment being what it is, striking a deal for anything less than a year is unthinkable. If this is all that Majority Leader Harry Reid can muster, then he needs to step aside. The press has been full of articles about how the Republicans need to save face but no one talks about how the Democrats need to win. Making a deal that takes us to January isn't a win for Democrats. Not by a long shot. This deal is a loser.

Gee, as I recall then-Senator Obama voted against raising the debt limit when Bush was President. It's only now that he and his party have doubled the national debt that he thinks it's not a problem.

By the way, I routinely read conservative literature and I have yet to hear ANYONE advocating default. Just one more case of a liberal extremist making up something silly and claiming his opponents hold that opinion. Are we sure that this isn't a White House press release?

Isn't it interesting that an issue related to the South's loss in the Civil War only begins to be taken seriously after we elect the first Black president? Why weren't these folks making so much noise all those times Congress voted to increase the debt ceiling under President Bush?

Anyway, what is "conservative" about the folks who are talking about default? Conservatives would not take -- let alone kill -- hostages. Conservatism is about preservation, not sudden and severe change. Default advocates are not conservatives. They are radical extremists. They seek massive change to bring about a vision of a government and a country that never existed. To refer to a small band of extremists, opposed by 90% of the American public, as "conservative" is a corruption and distortion of the term. They are radicals and should be referred to that way.

Of course, there is that pesky first amendment to dispense with first.  Oh, and getting rid of the legislative process and public debate so that the entertainment industry lobby won't be able to get in the way.  Governor Brown might want to talk to talk to his colleague Cuomo and trade notes.  He could declare a state of emergency maybe.

And how do those urban youths obtain their legally manufactured and legally sold, at least once, firearms?

Gee, that's a total black box, eh?

http://www.rolim.com.br/2002/_pdfs/ing.pdf
PREVENTING CRIME: WHAT WORKS, WHAT DOESN'T, WHAT'S PROMISING1
A REPORT TO THE UNITED STATES CONGRESS

Primary Conclusion. …..Given the evidence of promising and effective programs, the Report finds that the effectiveness of Department of Justice funding depends heavily on whether it is directed to the urban neighborhoods where youth violence is highly concentrated. Substantial reductions in national rates of serious crime can only be achieved by prevention in areas of concentrated poverty, where the majority of all homicides in the nation occur, and where homicide rates are 20 times the national average.

CONCLUSIONS
This chapter has shown that there is a substantial disconnection between what is known about community causes of serious violence and what this nation is doing about those causes. The scientific evidence that communities matter is strong. The evidence that serious crime is concentrated in a very small number of communities is even stronger. But the link between those facts and the design of prevention programs is very thin indeed. Instead, a National Academy of Sciences report concludes there is evidence that federal and local transportation and housing policies over the past half-century have substantially contributed to the causation of serious crime, especially in the hypersegregated inner cities where over half of all homicides occur.
Immediately sending a case of something sudsy to The BruMaster! Do it up in style ---only two more years till we stop feeding you !

This was a correct RegEx for the patterns in this puzzle:

163 results for regular expression ^M[AEIOU]C(.{5}|.{6}|.{12})$

Sorry there was no MICHELOB in my results. Do you believe a beer-themed puzzle would fly at NYT?

Better yet:

163 results for RegEx ^M[AEIOU]C(.{5,6}|.{12})$

One feature of RegEx that bugs me is that ranges are represented by dashes inside [these] brackets and commas inside {these}. Usually computer language designers are more consistent.

This theme is almost four times as popular as yesterdays US- theme. That surprised me. I would have thought more than five times!

199 results for regular expression ^M[AEIOU]C.{5,6}(.{6})?$

(8, 9 or 15 letter words which don't appear!)

MACADAMIA MACADAMS MACANESE MACARENA MACARONI MACARONIC MACAROON MACAROONS MACARTHUR MACASSAR MACAULAY MACCABEES MACDOWELL MACEDOINE MACEDONIA MACERATE MACGREGOR MACGUFFIN MACGYVER MACHETES MACHILID MACHINATE MACHINERY MACHINES MACHINIST MACHISMO MACHMETER MACHOMAN MACINTOSH MACKENZIE MACKEREL MACKINAW MACLAINE MACLEAYA MACLEISH MACONDOR MACONNAIS MACRAMES MACROCOSM MACROCYTE MACROGLIA MACROPUS MACROTIS MACROTUS MACTRUCKS MACULATE MACUSHLA MECHANIC MECHANICS MECHANISE MECHANISM MECHANIST MECHANIZE MECHANTS MECHOLYL MECLIZINE MECLOMEN MECONIUM MECOPTERA MICACEOUS MICAWBER MICHELIN MICHELLE MICHELNEY MICHELSON MICHENER MICHIGAN MICKSWELL MICROBAR MICROBAT MICROBES MICROBIAL MICROBIC MICROCHIP MICROCODE MICROCOOK MICROCOPY MICROCOSM MICROCYTE MICRODOT MICRODOTS MICROFILM MICROGLIA MICROGRAM MICROLITE MICROMYX MICRONASE MICRONOR MICROPYLE MICROSOME MICROTOME MICROTUS MICROVOLT MICROWATT MICROWAVE MICROZIDE MICRSCPIC MICRURUS MICTURATE MOCASSIN MOCCASIN MOCCASINS MOCKERNUT MOCKINGLY MUCHACHO MUCHNESS MUCICACID MUCILAGE MUCINOID MUCINOUS MUCKABOUT MUCKHEAP MUCKHILL MUCKRAKE MUCKRAKER MUCOIDAL MUCORALES

Greece put every man, woman, and child on government payrolls, and now they're all starving together as a result. They were/are about as much of an example as to what to do about inequality as Mao's Great Leap Forward.

In Chile, Mexico, and Turkey, birth rates dropped dramatically, and, as such, adults had more time to devote to education and training, thus providing a more skilled, prosperous workforce. In addition, lower birth rates meant fewer children born into poverty and allowed families to spend more per child, resulting in better outcomes for children.
It's probably the latter. I see no hint that sanity has returned to the House.

It's the Democrats who seem to believe the fantasy of perpetual motion for the economy - they seem to believe that we can just keep spending money forever and not have it come back to "pay the piper".
For a minute it sounded like would were describing the Chicago politics play book for governing.  Sol is smiling in his grave.

"One thing to remember is that not all the Republicans are in "safe" districts. This is actually good news for the Democrats (and the rest of us). "

Like this...

May the best man win!

"My" congressman is Scott Garrett. This is by no means a "safe" seat for him. I  voted Green Party for Congress last time because the Democratic candidate was no bargain either. (NJ lost a district because of the census and Steve Rothman, the liberal Democratic incumbent of one of the merged districts, chose to oppose another Democrat, leaving Garrett relatively unchallenged). However, voters should put almost all other considerations aside to make sure this is Garrett's last term. (And to make sure the Democrats nominate someone worth voting for.

One thing to remember is that not all the Republicans are in "safe" districts. This is actually good news for the Democrats (and the rest of us).

If the Tea Party types mount primary challenges against Republicans in competitive districts who vote for this compromise (assuming Boehner brings it to a vote), one of two things will happen: (1) the "moderate" Republican incumbent will win the primary but will be weakened and could lose the general election, or, (2), the moderate Republican will lose the primary, and a Tea Party nut job will be the party's nominee. In the second case, the seat is even more likely to go to a Democrat, because the voting public is pretty sick of these nut jobs and their shenanigans.

Either way, the Democrats will pick up seats — possibly enough to win back the house if things get bad enough.

The Senate compromise will probably pass — it will be interesting to see what Boenhner does. If he's got any brains, he'll bring it to a vote, because defaulting on the debt, even a little, will cause enough economic chaos to ensure that the Republicans loose the House.

Agreed.  Once again the Democrats have demonstrated that threats work.  It does not matter "how much" the Democrats caved, but just that they caved at all.  To announce, as they always do, that they will not negotiate under a threat or that they will not make any changes to ACA and then...negotiate AND make changes is suicidal.

I don't disagree with PK often but in this case I do.  Any concessions in the face of threats to destroy the world economy will only encourage the more radical elements of the republican party to do this again and again and I see concessions here.  I believe it is within the executive branch's power to override this ridiculous debt ceiling law and put an end to the foolishness once and for all.

I think the analysis is off base as to what "clutch" means. I don't think we are so much comparing "Player X" to himself so much as other players that could be in that position. So when you are in a "clutch situation" you want the player that will perform up to their ability at that moment. As your statistics point out, David Ortiz, or Derek Jeter perform equal to or slightly better than what they normally do. And as someone suggested, less "clutch" players might tend to perform not as good as they normally do in the same situation for a mid-season game in the first inning.

Also your "statistical scenarios" are not nuanced enough to define "clutch situation". Tied in last inning of Game 1 of ALCS, versus Game 7 is degrees of magnitude different for "clutch-ness". The fan will quantify that and value the hit in Game 7 way more than Game 1.

Finally, you are attempting to discount the emotional response and the "dark matter" of sports which is: Momentum. While hard to quantify, anyone who has played sports on any level can tell you there is a force of momentum that takes hold, or surrounds certain events or players that may lead to a "clutch reputation" but may not show up in your stats. To paraphrase above: "I can't see the tide changing, but I can tell if its low or high."

Steve Brown . Arizona

Americanism, as defined in the Webster Dictionary..."devotion or loyalty to the U.S. or to its traditions, customs, institutions, etc."

A broad statement open to debate for all Americans.

There is no denying that any American that voices opinion of decent, concerning our government in Washington, is accused as being something negative and demeaning. On the flip side, it is those that are "lazy"...that do not think for themselves, and accept "this mess" that our politicians have created...are most likely to be the "uninformed."

Americanism will not be tolerated in Washington by political leaders...in other words..."devotion or loyalty to the party lines" is first and foremost.

The magic of markets. Your loss is their gain. Their profits trump your needs. Any regulation to protect your needs is "socialism",  Get that pesky government off my back and let those markets work their magic.

I replaced my copper for FiOS 3 years ago; Verizon didn't tell me it didn't work in power outages until AFTER it had been installed.  Had I known that, I don't know that I would have changed over.  FiOS is great for internet, but I didn't like having no phone service during the Sandy aftermath.  Sure there's a battery, but it dies in, what 8 hours?  When is the power out for only 8 hours?  And after that, you can't recharge it.  You have to ante up another $25 for a new battery.  If local subscribers are to have NO communications during storms, etc., then other parts of the infrastructure (fire, police, ambulances) will have to change their protocols to meet our needs.  The phone company's savings will simply move costs to another category.

It depends on the level of technology we're talking about. Your wireline (landline) phone is subject to casual attack, trivially-easy attack by anyone who knows where your Network Interface box is. It's also subject to trivially-simple, undetectable wiretapping by the authorities.

Your modern cellular mobile phone is immune to casual wiretapping, but offers the exact same vulnerabilities to the authorities.

Other wireless technologies vary over the range from trivially easy (anyone with a radio scanner) to "just like a cell phone".
Ask the NSA.
Is wireless as secure as landlines?  Conversations with the doctor, the lawyer - are they as private?

One might guess that they have had at least a few economists who have articulated the Asian model.

Give just a wee-bit more time to the "Asian Model" before exalting its virtues. Two of the three nations you mention are not the brightest students of "democracy".

In fact, they are simply conformal copies of dated Mandarin political structures, with an elite at the top and worker-ants at the bottom.
